title: Covid-19 | Nutrition Guide for Clinicians
description: Covid-19 was found in Nutrition Guide for Clinicians, trusted medicine information.
cleaned_text: Covid-19 In December 2019, a novel coronavirus, severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), emerged in Wuhan, China, causing pneumonia and fatal respiratory illness now known as Covid-19. The virus has since spread worldwide. New variants continue to arise, most notably the delta and omicron strains, both of which disseminate more effectively than the strain causing the initial pandemic wave. Risk Factors Risk Factors Risk Factors Covid-19 has a more severe course in older people and those with underlying health conditions. [[1]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref32240123) Early in the pandemic, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported that, among individuals hospitalized for Covid-19 infections as of March 30, 2020, 43% were aged 65 and over, 50% had hypertension, 48% had a body mass index (BMI) 30, 35% had chronic lung disease, 28% had diabetes mellitus, and 28% had cardiovascular disease. [[2]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref32298251) As the pandemic spread to the United States, obesity, diabetes, and hypertension were commonly reported among hospitalized Covid-19 patients. [[3]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref32320003) These health conditions contribute to racial disparities in Covid-19 morbidity and mortality. In the US, Black persons comprise 13% of the population but accounted for one-third of hospitalizations early in the pandemic. [[2]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref32298251) In subsequent reports, Covid-19 death rates have remained much higher among Black and Hispanic persons, compared with non-Hispanic White persons. [[4]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref1628608010700) This disproportionate toll is caused, not by race or ethnicity per se, but by differences in socioeconomic factors (e.g., access to care) and in underlying health conditions. In a retrospective cohort study conducted by Ochsner Health in Louisiana, after adjusting for differences in sociodemographic and clinical characteristics on admission, Black race was not associated with higher in-hospital mortality than White race. [[5]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref32459916) This finding suggests that measures taken to improve these chronic health conditions may have a secondary benefit in reducing the consequences of infection with Covid-19. Excess body fat. Prior to the emergence of Covid-19, obesity was known to increase the risk of developing respiratory tract infections, including viral influenzas such as H1N1. [[6]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref22634305) Among California adults who contracted H1N1 infection in 2009, half had a BMI 30. [[7]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref21208911) Obesity also worsens the clinical course and increases mortality when influenza occurs. [[8]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref22546772) In the context of Covid-19, having a BMI 30 is an independent risk factor for the need for invasive mechanical ventilation in patients hospitalized with Covid-19. [[9]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref32352637) Compared with hospitalized Covid-19 inpatients with BMI < 25, those with BMI 35 have 7.4-fold increased odds of requiring invasive mechanical ventilation. [[10]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref32271993) Among the possible explanations for the relationship between obesity and adverse outcomes in Covid-19 is the fact that excess body weight increases the risk for lung diseases in general (e.g., asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease), as well as cardiometabolic diseases (e.g., hypertension, diabetes, and cardiovascular disease) that may reduce defenses and complicate survival. In addition, excess body weight may impair immune cell function and increase white blood cell counts. [[3]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref32320003), [[11]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref30458019) Individuals with a BMI 30 typically have a poorer immune response to influenza vaccines. [[12]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref22024641) Epicardial adipose tissue has also been implicated as a contributor to the cardiopulmonary complications of Covid-19, including myocarditis, which is postulated to be mediated by upregulation of inflammatory cytokines such as IL-6. [[13]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref32464641) Hypertension. Patients with preexisting hypertension are at excess risk of developing severe and fatal Covid-19 infections. [[3]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref32320003), [[14]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref32868984) Hypertension damages the cardiovascular system, presumably making affected individuals more susceptible to virus-induced heart disease. Diabetes. According to findings from a retrospective multicentered study of 7,337 Covid-19 cases in Hubei province, China, individuals with type 2 diabetes were much more likely to succumb to the disease, compared with individuals who did not have diabetes (7.8% vs 2.7%). Among those with type 2 diabetes, those with poor glucose control (hemoglobin A1C averaging 8.1%) had an in-hospital death rate of 11.0%. Those with good glucose control (hemoglobin A1C averaging 7.3%) had an in-hospital death rate of 1.1% and were less likely to experience organ damage or require medical interventions. [[15]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref32369736) Among 1,122 patients hospitalized with Covid-19 in 88 US hospitals, mortality rate was 28.8% among those with evidence of type 2 diabetes or uncontrolled hyperglycemia compared with 6.2% among those without diabetes or hyperglycemia. [[16]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref32389027) Patients with diabetes are estimated to have a 50% greater likelihood of fatal Covid-19 than nondiabetic SARS-CoV-2-infected patients. [[14]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref32868984) A study published in November 2021 reviewed more than 900,000 Covid-19-related US hospitalizations and found 63.5% were attributable to cardiometabolic conditions, including obesity, hypertension, and diabetes mellitus. [[17]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref33629868) Diagnosis Diagnosis Diagnosis Covid-19 is clinically similar to other influenza-like illnesses and respiratory tract infections, apart from the near-pathognomonic features of anosmia and dysgeusia. Microbiological confirmation of SARS-CoV-2 infection is therefore recommended. Current diagnosis of Covid-19 rests on either molecular detection of SARS-CoV-2 nucleic acid using tests such as polymerase chain reaction (PCR) or detection of viral antigen (protein) using point-of-care tests or immunoassays of clinical specimens such as nasopharyngeal swabs, nasal or oral swabs, saliva, sputum, and endotracheal aspirates. [[18]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref1628608904903) Detection of antibodies to SARS-CoV-2 by serological immunoassays has limited utility in the setting of acute Covid-19 illness due to more prolonged time for test processing and high rates of false negatives during the first few days of illness. Thus, serology tests for SARS-CoV-2 antibodies should be used to neither confirm nor exclude Covid-19 illness in acutely sick individuals. Rather, serology contributes more to the overall surveillance strategy for SARS-CoV-2 at a population level. Due to the evolving nature of laboratory testing for Covid-19 illness, it is recommended that authoritative sources such as the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention or the World Health Organization be consulted for the most up-to-date testing guidance. [[19]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref1628608918260) Prevention Prevention Prevention Three Covid-19 vaccines are currently authorized or approved for use in the US to prevent Covid-19. Two are mRNA vaccines (Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna), and the third is a viral vector vaccine (Johnson & Johnson/Janssen). Other vaccines are in use elsewhere. Evidence from clinical trials revealed the mRNA vaccines from Pfizer and Moderna were 95% and 94.1% effective at preventing Covid-19 in individuals who received 2 doses of the vaccine, respectively. The Johnson & Johnson viral vector vaccine was 66.3% effective at preventing Covid-19. Although the vaccines vary in protection against infection, all provide substantive protection against severe disease and hospitalization. Covid-19 vaccines have been deemed generally safe and effective. Safety data report the most common side effects related to vaccination are swelling, erythema and pain at the injection site, fever, headache, fatigue, myalgias, chills, and nausea. Serious adverse events are rare but have been reported, including thrombosis with thrombocytopenia syndrome, myocarditis and pericarditis, and Guillain-Barré syndrome. Evidence arose in mid-2021 suggesting reduced protection over time especially in special at-risk populations, particularly elderly and immunocompromised individuals. In response to this and ongoing data collection, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention now recommends booster vaccine shots be administered at least 5 months after completing the primary vaccination series for the mRNA-based vaccine and 2 months after completing primary vaccination with the Johnson & Johnson vaccine. Treatment Treatment Treatment Treatment guidelines for Covid-19 continue to evolve and are available from the National Institutes of Health (NIH). [[20]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref1628608932773) The mainstays of nonpharmacologic interventions for mild Covid-19—like many viral illnesses—are supportive and include adequate hydration and rest. Pharmacologic interventions for mild Covid-19 illness are aimed at symptom management and may include over-the-counter analgesics and antipyretics for fever, headache, and for sinusitis and rhinorrhea; and antitussives and expectorants for cough. In the vast majority of people with a mild Covid-19 illness, rapid resolution of symptoms is complete and without complications. For outpatients with mild to moderate Covid-19 with comorbidities that place them at high risk of clinical deterioration, the NIH recommends treatment with an anti-SARS-CoV-2 monoclonal antibody combination such as bamlanivimab plus etesevimab or casirivimab plus imdevimab. Both combinations are authorized for emergency use by the Food and Drug Administration. [[21]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref1628608948466) For patients with moderate to severe Covid-19 illness requiring hospitalization and/or intensive care, interventions can be broadly categorized into positioning; supportive interventions to ensure hemodynamic stability and adequate renal perfusion; targeted pharmacologic treatments (e.g., antivirals); immune-based therapies (e.g., blood-derived products, antibodies, and immunomodulators); and adjunctive interventions. Positional interventions, such as awake pronation and head elevation for the more moderately to severely ill Covid-19 patient, aim to improve oxygenation by reducing the diaphragmatic force against which infiltrated lungs must inflate. Use of targeted drug treatments should be guided by best available evidence and national authoritative guidelines, such as those produced by the NIH. [[20]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref1628608932773) At present, the antiviral remdesivir is the only targeted pharmacologic treatment for Covid-19 approved and licensed by the Food and Drug Administration and is recommended for hospitalized adults requiring supplemental oxygen. [[22]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref1628609041258) For those hospitalized and requiring supplemental oxygen and/or mechanical ventilation, the corticosteroid dexamethasone is recommended. The recommendation for use of corticosteroids in severe or critically ill Covid-19 patients is echoed by World Health Organization clinical practice guidelines. [[23]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref1628609056240) Tocilizumab, the recombinant anti-interleukin-6 receptor monoclonal antibody, should be added to dexamethasone (with or without remdesivir, depending on clinical status) for hospitalized Covid-19 patients experiencing rapid respiratory deterioration. For hospitalized Covid-19 patients on high-flow oxygen or noninvasive ventilation who are progressing clinically or are demonstrating increased markers of inflammation, the NIH recommends using either baricitinib (the oral Janus kinase inhibitor) or tocilizumab, combined with dexamethasone alone or dexamethasone plus remdesivir. At the time of this writing, with few exceptions, the NIH generally recommends against the use of convalescent plasma for treatment of Covid-19; the NIH also recommends against the use of other blood-derived products outside of clinical trials. [[20]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref1628608932773) For hospitalized adults or children, agents to prevent the formation of blood clots are recommended, but thrombolytic agents (which target existing clots) are not. [[20]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref1628608932773) Nutritional Considerations Nutritional Considerations Nutritional Considerations In the Covid-19 pandemic, several important roles for nutrition have emerged: Diet and Underlying Health Conditions Diet and Underlying Health Conditions Diet and Underlying Health Conditions Nutritional factors are key for the prevention and amelioration of the underlying health conditions that increase Covid-19 morbidity and mortality, particularly obesity, diabetes, and hypertension. A low-fat plant-based diet significantly improves control in each of these conditions and is superior in safety and efficacy, compared with other therapeutic diets (see respective chapters). Diet and Disease Severity Diet and Disease Severity Diet and Disease Severity Studies suggest that one's habitual dietary pattern may influence the severity of Covid-19 infection. Plant-based and Mediterranean diets appear to be associated with reduced risk, while low-carbohydrate diets appear to be associated with increased risk. Plant-based diets. In a study of health care workers with substantial SARS-CoV-2 exposure in the UK, US, Germany, France, Italy, and Spain in 2020, those who reported having followed either a "vegetarian" diet or a "whole food plant-based" diet during the year prior to the Covid-19 pandemic were 73% less likely to have moderate to severe Covid-19, compared with other individuals (OR 0.27, 95% CI 0.10 to 0.81). When individuals eating fish were included, the results were slightly less favorable. Among those following a "vegetarian," "whole food plant-based," or "pescatarian" diet, the risk of moderate to severe infection was 59% lower than for those following other diet patterns (OR 0.41, 95% CI 0.17 to 0.99). [[24]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref34308134) The smartphone-based COVID Symptom Study, including 92,571 participants, produced similar findings. Habitual consumption of fruits, vegetables, and other healthful plant-derived foods was used to generate a "healthful plant-based diet score." Compared with those with the lowest diet scores, those in the highest quartile were 41% less likely to develop severe Covid-19 (HR 0.59; 95% CI, 0.47-0.74) and 9% less likely to develop Covid-19 of any severity (HR 0.91; 95% CI 0.88 to 0.94). [[25]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref1628609099789) In Taiwan, a retrospective evaluation of individuals aged 65 years previously diagnosed with Covid-19 revealed that disease severity was inversely associated with adherence to a vegetarian diet (p = 0.013). Individuals following nonvegetarian dietary patterns had a greatly increased risk of critically severe Covid-19 (adjusted OR 5.434, p = 0.005). [[26]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref35571931) Mediterranean diets. Adherence to a Mediterranean dietary pattern was assessed in 5,194 individuals in Spain, using a food frequency questionnaire. Those with the highest adherence were less likely to have tested positive for Covid-19, compared with those with the lowest adherence to such a diet (OR 0.36, 95% CI: 0.16-0.84, p for trend < 0.001). These diet-related differences were identified only in laypersons and were not replicated among health professionals. [[27]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref33934925) In a study comparing the diets of 17 regions of Spain, greater adherence to a Mediterranean diet pattern was associated with reduced Covid-19 cases (r2 = 0.663) and reduced Covid-19-related mortality (r2 = 0.729). Similarly, a comparison of 23 countries found a negative association between Mediterranean Adequacy Index score and Covid-19-related mortality (r2 = 0.768, p = 0.004). [[28]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref33748170) The authors speculated that the apparent benefit of the diet may have been related to an anti-inflammatory effect of dietary polyphenols. Low-carbohydrate diets. Low-carbohydrate diets appear to be associated with adverse outcomes. In the study of health care workers in 6 countries described above, individuals following "low-carbohydrate, high-protein" diets were 48% more likely to have severe Covid-19 (OR 1.48, 95% CI 0.89 to 2.49). [[24]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref34308134) Individuals following these diets were nearly 4 times more likely to have moderate to severe Covid-19, compared with those following plant-based diets (OR 3.96, 95% CI 1.14 to 13.75, p < 0.05 for all tests). Diet and Vaccine Effectiveness Diet and Vaccine Effectiveness Diet and Vaccine Effectiveness Dietary factors may influence the effectiveness of vaccination due to their effect on underlying conditions that modulate immune response. Increased body weight was already known to be associated with a poorer immune response to influenza vaccines well before the Covid-19 pandemic. [[12]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref22024641) Response to the Pfizer Covid-19 vaccine was shown in a 2021 study to be impaired by increased waist circumference, hypertension, and high plasma cholesterol concentrations. [[29]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref33955644) First, excess body weight can increase the distance between skin surface and muscle tissue causing vaccine injections to be more likely to be subcutaneous, rather than intramuscular, potentially reducing their effectiveness. [[30]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref34275671) In addition, adiposity causes a low-grade inflammation that may reduce immune response. [[10]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref32271993) Dietary patterns greatly influence the risk of weight gain, hypertension, and dyslipidemia, all of which may, in turn, influence vaccine effectiveness. Meat Products as Fomites Meat Products as Fomites Meat Products as Fomites Apart from meat's role in dietary patterns, its role in coronavirus transmission has been of research interest, particularly since bats, the natural coronavirus hosts, have been sold in markets where transmission to humans was suspected. The survival of coronaviruses on meat samples has been tested. Studies adding SARS-CoV-2 to salmon, chicken, and pork samples have shown that the virus easily survives at refrigerated (4°C) or freezing (-20°C) temperatures. [[31]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref1670616658061), [[32]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref1670616713111) Similarly, a study using SARS-CoV-2 surrogates found viral survival at high concentrations on salmon, chicken, beef, and pork at both refrigerated and frozen temperatures after 30 days. [[33]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref35670583) While the primary human-to-human route of SARS-CoV-2 transmission is via airborne droplets or aerosols, these studies suggest that meat products represent an additional means of transmission and distribution. Nutritional Issues under Investigation Nutritional Issues under Investigation Nutritional Issues under Investigation Apart from the above considerations, many nutrients (e.g., dietary fat, vitamins C or D, selenium, zinc) and foods (e.g., fruits and vegetables in general, allium vegetables) have been investigated for their ability to influence lung function. However, their role in influencing the course of a SARS-CoV-2 infection is not yet well characterized. Key findings are described below. Vitamin C Vitamin C Vitamin C Vitamin C, or L-ascorbic acid, is a water-soluble vitamin found in fruits and vegetables, especially citrus fruits, peppers, broccoli, sweet potatoes, and strawberries. [[34]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref1628609113670) Several studies have supported the beneficial effects of vitamin C on immune function. [[35]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref16373990), [[36]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref20515554), [[37]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref22070691), [[38]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref29099763) A deficiency may lead to immune impairments and a higher risk of infections. A study including 57 hospitalized elderly patients with acute respiratory infections showed a benefit of vitamin C supplements over placebo. [[39]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref7814237) An early review of acute respiratory infections and vitamin C found benefits for reducing the duration and/or severity of symptoms. Three controlled studies each found at least an 80% reduction in the risk of developing pneumonia among those taking vitamin C. Preventive benefits of supplementation may be more likely in those with marginal deficiency or under physical stress. [[40]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref10488881) A 2013 review examined placebo-controlled trials of vitamin C for the common cold. Vitamin C supplementation did not reduce the incidence of colds (29 trials) except in individuals under extreme physical stress (5 trials). Regular use of vitamin C supplements did modestly reduce the duration of symptoms (31 trials). [[41]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref23440782) A recent randomized controlled trial of vitamin C infusion in 167 critically ill patients with sepsis-induced ARDS demonstrated a significant 28-day mortality benefit: 29.8% in the vitamin C arm vs 46.3% in the placebo arm. [[42]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref31573637) In the setting of Covid-19, the NIH reports that at present there are insufficient data to recommend either for or against adjunctive or stand-alone vitamin C for treatment of mild, moderate, or severe SARS-CoV-2 infections. [[43]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref1628609592473) Severe vitamin C deficiency is frequently complicated by pneumonia, which is among the most common causes of mortality in the Covid-19 patient population. [[44]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref32546195) Vitamin D Vitamin D Vitamin D The human body produces vitamin D when UVB solar radiation strikes the skin. Darker skin, winter season, use of sunscreen, older age, and indoor time all reduce endogenous production. Vitamin D is essential to many processes in the body including calcium homeostasis and bone health, regulation of cell growth and differentiation, and neuromuscular and immune function. [[45]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref1628609632214) Observational and supplementation trials have suggested that higher circulating 25-hydroxy vitamin D (25(OH)D) concentrations are associated with reduced risk of several infectious diseases, including influenza, dengue, hepatitis, herpesvirus, and pneumonia. [[46]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref32252338), [[47]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref31185932), [[48]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref31145049), [[49]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref32395364) A of 25 randomized controlled trials, including data from 10,933 participants, showed that vitamin D supplementation decreased the risk of respiratory infections by 12%. Among those with baseline vitamin D levels below 10 ng/mL (25 nmol/L), the reduction in risk was 70%. [[50]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref30675873) Regarding Covid-19 specifically, a recent review identified multiple lines of suggestive evidence for vitamin D's role, including that the outbreak began in the northern hemisphere where it was winter, when 25(OH)D levels are lowest; cases in the southern hemisphere, where the pandemic struck in late summer, were relatively low; vitamin D deficiency can worsen acute respiratory distress syndrome; and case fatality increases with age and chronic disease comorbidity, both of which are linked to lower 25(OH)D levels. Furthermore, several studies across geographies have demonstrated lower overall serum vitamin D levels in Covid-19 patients compared with healthy population controls. Mechanisms by which vitamin D may be protective include induction of antiviral peptides, and decreased production of pro-inflammatory cytokines that can injure the lungs and cause pneumonia. [[39]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref7814237) Observational data for use of vitamin D in Covid-19 have yielded ambiguous findings. In 185 Covid-19 patients diagnosed and treated in Heidelberg, Germany, whose vitamin D status was examined retrospectively, age-, sex-, and comorbidity-adjusted vitamin D deficiency (< 12 ng/mL [< 30 nM]) was highly correlated to both increased risk of invasive mechanical ventilation (> 6-fold risk) and death (> 14-fold risk). [[51]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref32927735) However, in a prospective, multicenter observational study of long-term outcomes in 109 Covid-19 patients with persistent symptoms in Austria and Germany, low serum vitamin D levels either acutely or at 2-month follow-up were not correlated to more persistent symptoms, functional lung impairment, or more significant abnormalities on CT scan, leading the authors to conclude that while vitamin D deficiency is common among Covid-19 patients, it is unrelated to disease outcomes. [[52]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref32932831) In a retrospective observational study matching SARS-CoV-2 test results to 25(OH)D levels from the prior year in more than 190,000 patients across the US, the authors conclude that "SARS-CoV-2 positivity is strongly and inversely associated with circulating 25(OH)D levels, a relationship that persists across latitudes, races/ethnicities, both sexes, and age ranges." [[53]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref32941512) The overall SARS-CoV-2 positivity rate among 191,779 tested individuals was 9.3%; however, positivity varied according to vitamin D level. For those with vitamin D deficiency (< 20 ng/mL; n = 39,190), positivity rate was 12.5%, while for those with adequate levels (30-34 ng/mL; n = 27,870), positivity rate was 8.1%, and for those with levels 55 ng/mL (n = 12.321), positivity rate was 5.9%. [[53]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref32941512) Prospective clinical trials of vitamin D as a therapeutic intervention for Covid-19 illness have also produced mixed results. In an open-label randomized clinical trial in Cordoba, Spain, 76 Covid-19 patients fulfilling hospital admission criteria were treated with standard of care with or without 25(OH)D supplementation. Only 1 patient in the 25(OH)D arm required ICU admission, and none died, compared with 50% ICU admission and 8% mortality in the arm without supplementation. Adjusted for the comorbidities hypertension and diabetes, odds of ICU admission with 25(OH)D treatment was 0.03. [[54]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref32871238) However, in a randomized, double-blind placebo-controlled trial in Brazil, which enrolled over 200 hospitalized patients with Covid-19, significant differences between the vitamin D and placebo arms for the outcomes of length of stay, ICU admission, need for invasive mechanical ventilation, or death were not observed. [[55]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref33595634) Taken together, the present state of evidence prevents recommendation either for or against the use of vitamin D as an adjunctive or stand-alone therapy for Covid-19. [[56]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref33595641), [[57]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref1628610858112) Zinc Zinc Zinc Zinc is an essential mineral found in legumes, nuts/seeds, oats, and meat. It plays an important role in immune function, and deficiency has been shown to adversely affect the function of T and B lymphocytes. [[58]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref27021581), [[59]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref29186856) Excess zinc can also impair immunity. [[60]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref23775705) Elderly populations are especially susceptible to zinc deficiency. They are also at risk for immune deficiencies and for respiratory infections. [[61]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref29558948) However, there is mixed evidence about the effectiveness of zinc supplementation on immune function in this population. One randomized controlled trial of zinc supplementation in elderly individuals found significantly reduced incidence of infections in the supplemented group. [[62]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref17344507) In contrast, a separate controlled study of zinc supplementation showed that up to 30 mg of zinc per day led to no significant long-term effects on immune status in healthy older adults. [[63]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref17595415) Zinc can also affect viruses directly. In cell-based studies, high levels of zinc ions (Zn2+) together with compounds that promote uptake of zinc into cells were found to inhibit replication of a variety of RNA viruses, including the original severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus (SARS-CoV). In assays measuring the activity of the SARS-CoV replication and transcription complex, without which the virus cannot multiply, Zn2+ efficiently inhibited synthesis of viral RNA. [[64]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref21079686) Whether zinc administration could benefit those with Covid-19 is under investigation. [[65]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref1628611125954) A review of 16 randomized, placebo-controlled trials of zinc supplementation for treatment of the common cold found a significant reduction in duration (by 1.03 days) but not severity of common cold symptoms. Data from 2 preventive trials indicated that those taking zinc prophylactically for 5 or more months had a 36% lower incidence rate ratio of developing a cold than those in the placebo group. [[60]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref23775705) The evidence base supporting the use of zinc supplementation as either a preventive or a therapeutic intervention in Covid-19 is particularly scant, and for this reason, the NIH treatment guidelines specifically recommend against its use as a preventive maneuver and cite the need for additional studies before a recommendation for or against its use as a therapeutic intervention can be made. [[66]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref1628611142041) One retrospective observational analysis compared outcomes in hospitalized Covid-19 patients in New York who received zinc supplementation or not in addition to hydroxychloroquine and azithromycin treatment. [[67]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref1628624996803) Of 932 enrollees, 44% received zinc, and 56% did not. Baseline differences potentially biasing data interpretation include higher total lymphocyte count and lower troponin and procalcitonin levels in those receiving zinc supplementation. Those who received zinc had lower mortality rates and higher likelihood of being discharged home, a finding that was most significant for patients being treated outside of an ICU setting. [[67]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref1628624996803) Selenium Selenium Selenium Selenium is an essential trace element that contributes to many biological processes including cellular protection against oxidative stresses as well as infection. Rich dietary sources of selenium include Brazil nuts, long-grain brown rice, oats, and baked beans; however, the most common sources of selenium in the American diet are bread, grains, meats including poultry and fish, and eggs. [[68]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref1628625019453) Selenium has been repeatedly demonstrated to have antiviral effects. [[69]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref31487871) The most compelling evidence of selenium's potential role in mitigation of viral-induced pathogenesis stems from our understanding of Keshan disease, in which the cardiomyopathy associated with selenium deficiency is mediated by intercurrent coxsackievirus infection, which also explains its seasonal variation. Population-level selenium supplementation in endemic areas has drastically reduced the incidence of Keshan disease. Selenium supplementation has also been found to confer morbidity and mortality benefits in other viral diseases, including HIV. [[70]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref25593145), [[71]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref9342257) In Covid-19, population-level studies have demonstrated an inverse relationship between selenium levels and mortality, with areas having the lowest dietary intakes and historic serum or hair concentrations suffering the greatest mortality rates. [[72]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref32342979) Similarly, areas known for high dietary intake demonstrated the lowest regional Covid-19 mortality rates. These population-level data from China have been corroborated in a cross-sectional study of hospitalized Covid-19 patients in Germany, in which selenium status was assessed consecutively in serum samples. Forty-four percent of Covid-19 patient specimens were found to be selenium deficient compared with reference controls, and deficiency was overrepresented among those Covid-19 patients who died: 65% in those who died vs. 39% in those who survived. [[73]](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342102/all/Covid_19#ref32708526) Several hypotheses have emerged to explain such findings, all of which require further prospective interrogation and accrual of high-quality data before a therapeutic role of selenium is considered in the Covid-19 patient population. Orders Orders Orders See [Basic Diet Orders](./view/Nutrition_Guide_for_Clinicians/1342084/all/Basic_Diet_Orders:_Teaching_Patients_Good_Health_Practices) chapter. What to Tell the Family What to Tell the Family What to Tell the Family Use of masks, personal hygiene, physical distancing, and vaccination remain key steps for preventing viral spread. The role of nutrition, particularly a low-fat, plant-based diet, is important in improving control of underlying conditions (obesity, diabetes, and hypertension) that increase Covid-19 pathogenicity. High-quality evidence to support specific foods or nutrients for treatment or prevention of Covid-19 is lacking; however, available data suggest that an overall dietary pattern that is plant-based and rich in vegetables, nuts, and legumes may reduce the risk of developing moderate to severe Covid-19.
